You are correct that the "painful nature of human existence," "prejudices and injustices," and "the power of empathy" are thematic topics that are explored in the novel. These topics can be considered as underlying messages or ideas that emerge from the story.

A theme, on the other hand, is a broader statement or insight that emerges from the work as a whole. A theme is often a universal or timeless truth that speaks to the human experience beyond the specific context of the story.

Here is a revised version of the theme statement that takes these distinctions into account:

To Kill a Mockingbird explores the difficult realities of life in a small Southern town during the Great Depression, illuminating the destructive impact of prejudice and injustice on individuals and communities. However, the novel also offers a message of hope through its portrayal of the transformative power of empathy and moral courage to challenge oppressive systems and bring about positive change. Ultimately, the novel suggests that the fight for justice and equality is a moral imperative that demands the engagement and commitment of all members of society.
